title: Samantha Power on What She’s Learned
text:
Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music | How to Listen

Samantha Power’s first book, “‘A Problem From Hell’: America in the Age of Genocide” (2002), won the Pulitzer Prize. Since its publication, she has written other books, worked as an adviser to Barack Obama and served as a United Nations ambassador. Her new book is a memoir, “The Education of an Idealist.” In his review, the Times columnist Thomas L. Friedman writes: “The interweaving of Power’s personal story, family story, diplomatic history and moral arguments is executed seamlessly — and with unblinking honesty.”

Image

On this week’s podcast, Power talks about why she wanted to write this particular book at this particular moment. “This seemed to me the best way to open up a world that I think has become too cloistered, too inside baseball-y, with foreign policy people talking to each other, government people talking to each other,” she says. She wanted to approach her own experience in a way so that “people are swept along with the story but as they go, they then understand the human rights crisis in the world, the refugee crisis in the world and, much more importantly, what one individual can do to try to deal with some of these issues.”

Craig Johnson visits the podcast this week to discuss his series of mystery novels featuring Walt Longmire, which have been turned into the television show “Longmire.” “What if you were the sheriff of the least populated county in the least populated state in America?” Johnson says of his inspiration for the Wyoming-set series. “It would force you to deal more with character and place, which is where I think the best writing comes from.”
description: Power talks about her new memoir, “The Education of an Idealist,” and Craig Johnson discusses his Longmire mysteries.
